Graphical abstract Employing density functional theory calculations combined with experimental studies, the structure-activity relationships and potential of pyrrole-type transition metal-N3 (TM-po-N3) as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) bifunctional catalysts were systematically explored. Efficient catalysis of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is essential for the rechargeable zinc-air batteries (R-ZABs). However, challenges remain due to the scarcity of effective bifunctional electrocatalysts and limited understanding of the structure-activity relationships. Pyrrole-type single-atom catalysts (SACs) with unique electronic structures have emerged as promising electrocatalysts. In this work, we combine density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental studies to systematically explore the structure-activity relationships and potential of pyrrole-type transition metal-N3 (TM-po-N3) as bifunctional catalysts. DFT calculations reveal that differences in the dependence of ORR and OER activities on the free energy of adsorption of reaction intermediates significantly affect the TM-po-N3 bifunctional activity and identify magnetic Cu-po-N3 as the best candidate. The bifunctional activity of Cu-po-N3 originates from interactions between spin-polarized out-of-plane Cu_3d and O_2s+2p orbitals. Theoretical predictions are validated experimentally, showing that the synthesized Cu-SAC/NC exhibits excellent bifunctional performance with a small potential gap of 0.666 V. Additionally, the assembled R-ZABs display a high-power density of 170 mW cm−2 and long-term stability, with the charge-discharge voltage gap increasing by only 0.01 V over 240 h. This work provides new insights into the design of efficient bifunctional catalysts. Keywords Rechargeable zinc-air battery Oxygen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Single-atom catalysts Structure-activity relationship 1 Introduction The growing demand for sustainable and efficient energy storage systems has intensified research into advanced battery technologies [1–6]. Among these technologies, rechargeable zinc-air batteries (R-ZABs) have emerged as a promising candidate due to their remarkably high theoretical energy density (1084 Wh kg−1) and inherent safety features [7–10]. The operational efficiency and power output of R-ZABs are predominantly governed by two electrochemical reactions: the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) during discharge and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during charge [10–12]. Platinum-based materials have excellent ORR activity, while ruthenium-based oxides can catalyze OER processes at low overpotentials [13–16]. However, the rarity and high price of noble metals limit the commercialization of related devices [17,18]. These catalysts that are active for either ORR or OER alone often fail to deliver optimal performance when being combined into R-ZABs due to issues such as poor compatibility, high costs, and manufacturing complexities [19–22]. Hence, the development of bifunctional catalysts that can efficiently catalyze both ORR and OER is imperative for enhancing the performance of R-ZABs [23–26]. Despite significant advancements [27–30], the design of non-noble bifunctional catalysts with high intrinsic activity remains challenging, primarily due to the sluggish kinetics associated with reversible oxygen reactions and limited understanding of their structure-activity relationships. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) featuring atomically dispersed transition metal (TM) sites have garnered prominence as non-noble candidates due to their extraordinary atomic utilization, tunable electronic structures, and promising activity for various electrocatalytic reactions [31–36]. Among the various types of SACs, pyridine-type single-atom catalysts (TM-pd-N), where the metal atom is coordinated by pyridine nitrogen atoms, have been extensively studied [37–42]. However, despite their promising attributes, the application of SACs in R-ZABs is limited by challenges such as insufficient bifunctional catalytic activity and stability under operational conditions [10]. Compared to pyridine nitrogen, pyrrole nitrogen exhibiting higher charge density is expected to form stronger TM–N bonds (Fig. 1 a). Adopting pyrrole nitrogen as a coordination atom for metal sites instead of pyridine nitrogen brings a new strategy to optimize the catalytic performance of SACs. Recent studies have indicated that pyrrole-type single-atom catalysts (TM-po-N), with pyrrole nitrogen atoms coordinating the metal, exhibit superior performance for oxygen activation compared to their pyridine-type counterparts [43,44]. These suggest that exploring new classes of SACs, particularly those with pyrrole-type coordination, could pave the way for developing more efficient bifunctional catalysts for R-ZABs. Building on these insights, our previous work has successfully designed pyrrole-type Cu-N3 sites (denoted as Cu-po-N3), which demonstrated high ORR activity through a combination of theoretical calculations and experimental validation [45]. This promising result motivated us to further investigate the potential application of this new class of single-atom catalysts in bifunctional oxygen reactions. In this contribution, we employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to evaluate the bifunctional activity of various TM-po-N3 catalysts and investigate their structure-activity relationships. We identified that Mn-po-N3, Co-po-N3, Ni-po-N3, Cu-po-N3, and Ag-po-N3 exhibit promising bifunctional catalytic properties. We found that the inconsistent dependence of the ORR and OER activities of the catalysts on ΔG a_OH and ΔG a_O-ΔG a_OH posed a challenge in achieving high ORR activity and high OER activity simultaneously. In particular, the Cu-po-N3 is predicted to exhibit excellent bifunctional activity with the smallest OER-ORR potential difference (ΔE OER-ORR). In-depth mechanistic explorations revealed that spin-polarized interactions between the 3dxz , 3dyz , and 3dz2 orbitals in Cu and the 2s+2p orbitals of O are the origin of the Cu-po-N3 bifunctional activity. Subsequent experimental characterization not only validated the superior activity of Cu-po-N3 but also confirmed the excellent performance of assembled R-ZABs based on as-prepared SAC-Cu/NC. The R-ZABs exhibit a high power density of 170 mW cm−2, a high open-circuit voltage of 1.49 V, and a high long-term cycling stability that the charge-discharge voltage gap only increases by 0.01 V after 240 h of charge-discharge tests. These findings underscore the efficacy of pyrrole-type single-atom catalysts in bifunctional oxygen reactions and highlight the potential of these catalysts in advancing the performance of R-ZABs. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structure and stability of TM-po-N3 As shown in Fig. 1(b), the single atom sites in TM-po-N3 contain one TM cation bound to three pyrrole-N anions. Tc, Cd, and Hg are toxic or radioactive elements, and the atomic structure of Pt-po-N3 is unable to be maintained during structural relaxation. Therefore, these four elements are excluded from our following calculations (Fig. 1c). We modeled TM-po-N3 for the remaining 25 transition metals from the 3d to 5d rows, and their atomic structures are displayed in Fig. S1. All structures maintained the pyrrole-type TM-N3 coordination configuration. In these models, Cu and Zn cations, which have small atomic radii, lie within the graphene plane with TM heights smaller than 0.03 Å (Table S1). In contrast, cations with larger atomic radii are positioned above the plane with heights ranging from 0.05 to 0.10 Å. The average TM–N bond lengths in most TM-po-N3 structures are comparable to or even shorter than those in the corresponding stable nitrides, indicating that pyrrolic nitrogen can reliably anchor metal cations to the carbon support (Fig. 1d). To assess the feasibility of experimentally synthesizing TM-po-N3 catalysts, we calculated their cluster energies (E clus) using the definition E clus = E bind − E coh, where E bind and E coh are the binding energy between metal atoms and the carbon support and the cohesive energy of the metal atoms aggregating to form bulk TM, respectively (see computational details in the Supporting Information). A negative E clus indicates that forming TM-po-N3 sites is thermodynamically more favorable than forming metal bulk. Apart from Co-, Ag-, Re-, Os-, Ir-, and Au-po-N3 with positive E clus, the remaining TM-po-N3 structures exhibit negative E clus, suggesting that they can resist Ostwald ripening and are expected to be experimentally synthesized (Fig. 1e and Table S2). The stability of TM-po-N3 in solution was evaluated by dissolution potentials (U diss, see Supporting Information for details). Negative U diss (Mn-, Co-, Y-, Nb-, Ag-, and Re-po-N3) indicates a tendency for TM ions to dissolve into the solution, while TM ions in TM-po-N3 with positive U diss tend to remain anchored on the carbon support. Practical SACs require the atomic disperse metal cations to be against not only Oswald ripening but also dissolution into the solution to be stably anchored on the support. Due to the strong binding between TM and pyrrole nitrogen, sixteen M−po−N3 (Sc-, Ti-, V-, Cr-, Fe-, Ni-, Cu-, Zn-, Zr-, Mo-, Ru-, Rh-, Pd-, Hf-, Ta-, and W-po-N3) meet these requirements (E clus < 0 eV and U diss > 0 V), covering most of transition metals, indicating that TM-po-N3 are a large class of potential stable electrocatalyst candidates. 2.2 Catalytic activity of TM-po-N3 Next, the catalytic activities of TM-po-N3 for two critical electrochemical reactions, ORR and OER, were investigated. A typical ORR and OER process involves four configurations: the pristine TM-po-N3, TM-po-N3 adsorbed with one OOH, O, and OH species, denoted as *, OOH*, O*, and OH*, respectively (Fig. 2 a). According to the calculated Gibbs free energy diagrams shown in Fig. 2(b) and Fig. S2, the ORR overpotentials (η ORR), OER overpotentials (η OER), and OER-ORR potential difference (ΔE OER-ORR = η ORR + η OER) are summarized in Fig. 2(c) and Table S3. Among these materials, the theoretical η ORR of Ni-, Cu-, and Ag-po-N3 is 0.53, 0.39, and 0.27 V, respectively, smaller than or comparable to that for Pt (η ORR = 0.45 V) [46]. ORR potential determining step (PDS) of Ni-po-N3 and Cu-po-N3 is the desorption of OH species (*OH → *), while for Ag-po-N3, it is the formation of O* (*OOH → O*). Mn-po-N3 (η OER = 0.40 V), Co-po-N3 (η OER = 0.39 V), and Cu-po-N3 (η OER = 0.45 V) exhibit comparable or higher OER activity than RuO2 (η OER = 0.41 V) [47]. Their OER overpotential is limited by the formation of O* (*OH → O*). The ΔE OER-ORR values for Mn-, Co-, Ni-, Cu-, and Ag-po-N3 are estimated to be 1.09, 1.08, 1.04, 0.84, and 1.05 V, respectively. However, Mn-, Co-, and Ag-po-N3 are unstable due to their positive E clus or negative U diss values. The remaining non-noble Ni- and Cu-po-N3 are potential bifunctional electrocatalysts. Interestingly, although Cu-po-N3 does not exhibit the best ORR or OER activity, it is the most active bifunctional material. This suggests that achieving high bifunctional activity requires the synergistic tuning of the Gibbs free-energy differences of each electron-transfer step rather than focusing on a single ORR PDS or OER PDS. 2.3 Structure-activity relationships of TM-po-N3 The catalytic activity of SAC is closely related to the central metal atom. Exploring the relationships between the type of metal and catalytic activity is essential for guiding catalyst design. The Gibbs free energies of adsorption (ΔG a) of OOH (ΔG a_OOH), O (ΔG a_O), and OH (ΔG a_OH) on TM-po-N3 are summarized in Fig. 3 (a–c). The ideal ΔG a_OOH, ΔG a_O, and ΔG a_OH are 3.69, 2.46, and 1.23 eV, respectively, as indicated by the dashed cyan line. Strong adsorption to these intermediates is prevalent in TM-po-N3, particularly for OH, where all TM-po-N3 exhibit ΔG a_OH values less than 1.23 eV. The adsorption characteristics of TM-po-N3 based on 4d and 5d transition metals significantly differ from those based on 3d transition metals. From 3d to 5d transition metal, ΔG a values become increasingly sensitive to changes in atomic number. For example, the smallest ΔG a_OOH for 3d and 4d TM-po-N3 is 2.74 and 0.80 eV, respectively, while for 5d TM-po-N3, it is down to −2.40 eV. Within 4d and 5d rows, the ΔG a values of the first (Y and Hf) and last TMs (Ag and Au) are close to the ideal values, whereas intermediate transition metals deviate significantly, forming a U-shaped relationship between ΔG a and atomic number. This U-shaped adsorption relationship further leads to a U-shaped relationship between activity and atomic number (Fig. 3d–f). The first and last metals exhibit the highest activity, while the intermediate metals are inert to ORR/OER due to the very negative ΔG a. It is speculated that scarcity of 4d and 5d transition metal-based SACs in bifunctional catalysts is related to this U-shaped relationship and the sensitivity of ΔG a to atomic number. In contrast, most 3d TM-po-N3 exhibit ΔG a values close to the optimal. For instance, all 3d TM-po-N3, except Ti-po-N3, have ΔG a_OOH values between 3.45 and 3.93 eV, within 0.24 eV of the optimal value. This explains why most catalysts exhibiting ORR or OER activity adopt 3d transition metals as active sites. For example, TM-po-N3 with η OER less than 0.60 V include Mn-, Fe-, Co-, Ni-, Cu-, and Au-po-N3, with five out of six being 3d TM-po-N3. Among the ten 3d TM-po-N3, Cu-po-N3 exhibits modest Gibbs free energies of adsorption for three related reaction intermediates (ΔG a_OOH = 3.93 eV, ΔG a_O = 2.52 eV, and ΔG a_OH = 0.84 eV), thus conferring the highest bifunctional activity. A complete ORR and OER cycle consists of four electron-transfer steps involving the interconversion of OOH, O, and OH. SAC activities are determined by the Gibbs free energy of adsorption of these three intermediates (ΔG a_OOH, ΔG a_O, and ΔG a_OH) at the metal sites. ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH and ΔG a_OH can be used as catalytic descriptors for OER and ORR [48–50], respectively (Fig. 4 a and b). Moreover, it is found that ΔG a_OH can also be adopted as a descriptor for the bifunctional activity of TM-po-N3 (Fig. 4c). A volcano relationship between η OER and ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH is fitted and the highest OER activity can be achieved at ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH = 1.11 eV. Most SACs show a volcano relationship between ORR activity and ΔG a_OH, where strong and weak OH adsorptions correspond to the left and right wings of the volcano, respectively [48,51,52]. For TM-po-N3, all of them exhibit strong OH adsorption (ΔG a_OH ≤ 1.00 eV). Therefore, only the left wings of the volcano relationship can be obtained in this work. Higher ORR and bifunctional activity may be achieved by the further weakening of OH adsorption on TM-po-N3. There are scaling relationships between the ΔG a of these intermediates. As displayed in Fig. 4(d), ΔG a_OOH follows a linear expression of ΔG a_OOH = 2.46 × ΔG a_OH + 2.54 (R 2 = 0.88). The linear relationship between ΔG a_O and ΔG a_OH is ΔG a_O = 2.06 × ΔG a_OH + 1.12 (R 2 = 0.98). Using these scaling relationships, Gibbs free energy of the four electron-transfer steps (ΔG 1 to ΔG 4, see Supporting Information) can be expressed with ΔG a_OH and ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH as independent variables. ΔG 1 = ΔG a_OH ΔG 2 = ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH ΔG 3 = 1.46ΔG a_OH − (ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH) + 2.54 ΔG 4 = − 2.46ΔG a_OH + 2.38 The η OER and η ORR are defined as η OER = max{ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, ΔG 4}/e −1.23 and η ORR = max{−ΔG 1, −ΔG 2, −ΔG 3, −ΔG 4}/e + 1.23, respectively. Therefore, a contour map of η OER and η ORR on TM-po-N3 can be established and depicted in Fig. 4(e and f). ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH of TM-po-N3 increases as the ΔG a_OH increases, indicating a positive correlation between them. The region with an overpotential smaller than 0.60 V, surrounded by the white dashed line, is regarded as the high-activity region (HAR). There are significant differences between the ORR and OER contour maps. (1) The shape of the HAR differs: the HAR in the OER contour map is triangular, whereas that in the ORR contour map is strip-shaped; (2) the location of the HARs is different: ΔG a_OH in the ORR HAR is generally larger, placing it to the right of the OER HAR; and (3) the sensitivity to ΔG a_OH and ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH varies: the ORR HAR has a narrower range of ΔG a_OH (0.63 eV < ΔG a_OH < 0.76 eV for ORR HAR and 0.25 eV < ΔG a_OH < 0.82 eV for OER HAR) and a broader distribution of ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH (0.62 eV < ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH < 2.84 eV for ORR HAR and 1.02 eV < ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH < 1.83 eV for OER HAR) compared to the OER HAR, revealing that ORR activity of TM-po-N3 is very sensitive to ΔG a_OH and less sensitive to ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH. These differences resulted in inconsistent dependence of the ORR and OER activities of the catalysts on ΔG a_OH and ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH, posing a challenge in obtaining high ORR activity and high OER activity at the same time. Further enhancement of TM-po-N3 requires modulation of the linear relationship between intermediates to regulate the dependence of activity on ΔG a_OH and ΔG a_O − ΔG a_OH. 2.4 Original of activity of Cu-po-N3 Elucidating the origin of the catalytic activity in Cu-po-N3 from its electronic structure provides critical insights for designing superior bifunctional SACs. Cu-po-N3 is identified as a magnetic single-atom catalyst (Fig. 5 a). The interaction of reaction intermediates and Cu during ORR and OER induces significant changes in the magnetic properties of the catalyst. The total magnetic moments of *, OOH*, O*, and OH* are 0.49, 0.62, 2.03, and 1.29 μB, respectively. Correspondingly, the local magnetic moments on Cu cations are 0.26, 0.33, 0.73, and 0.59 μB, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the local magnetic moment of Cu in pristine Cu-po-N3 is primarily contributed by the 3dxy orbitals. Upon adsorption of OOH, O, and OH, the contributions shift to the 3dxz and 3dyz orbitals. Interestingly, local magnetic moments are not confined to the Cu cations but are also present on the intermediates, with values of 0.18 μB for OOH, 0.77 μB for O, and 0.17 μB for OH. These local magnetic moments originate from the 2p orbitals of oxygen anions. Specifically, the local magnetic moments in OOH and OH are predominantly from the 2pz orbitals, while those in O arise from the 2px and 2py orbitals (Fig. 5c). The presence of non-zero local magnetic moments in both Cu sites and intermediates indicates a spin-polarized electronic structure (Fig. S3). This spin-polarized electronic structure results in spin-polarized interactions between intermediates and metal sites (Fig. 5d and Fig. S4). The Cu–O bonds are decomposed into interactions between the five 3d orbitals of Cu and the 2s+2p orbitals of O using the integral crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) technique. Significant orbital overlap is observed between the out-of-plane orbitals (3dxz , 3dyz , and 3dz 2) of Cu and the 2s+2p orbitals of O, while minimal overlap occurs between the in-plane orbitals (3dx 2 -y 2 and 3dxy ) and the 2s+2p orbitals. The spin-polarized interactions between the out-of-plane orbitals and the 2s+2p orbitals are confirmed by the different ICOHP values at the Fermi level in the spin-up and spin-down channels (Table S4). Therefore, the spin-polarized out-of-plane orbitals, rather than the in-plane orbitals, play a crucial role in forming the chemical bond between Cu and the oxygenated intermediates. These spin-polarized interactions are fundamental to the excellent bifunctional activity of Cu-po-N3 catalysts. 2.5 Performance of rechargeable ZABs based on Cu-po-N3 To verify the bifunctional OER and ORR activity of Cu-po-N3, a SAC-Cu/NC catalyst was synthesized via the plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) treatment method reported in our recently reported work [45]. First, Cu foam and nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) were used as metal and supported precursors, respectively, and SAC-Cu/NC catalysts were obtained by PECVD (the morphology and structural characterizations of the NC are shown in Figs. S5 and S6). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and X-ray diffractometer (XRD) images showed no signals of Cu clusters or nanoparticles in the prepared SAC-Cu/NC after plasma treatment (Fig. 6 a and b and Figs. S7 and S8). Notably, the two distinct broad peaks located at about 21° and 44° in the XRD pattern of SAC-Cu/NC are the (202) and (101) faces of graphitic carbon, and no peaks of Cu crystals were detected. The dispersion of metal atoms on the support was observed by aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM). The AC-HAADF-STEM images showed that the Cu atoms were dispersed on the support, which further demonstrated the success of the preparation of SAC-Cu/NC catalysts (Fig. 6c). Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) images showed that the C, N, and Cu of SAC-Cu/NC were uniformly dispersed on the supports (Fig. 6d). Based on Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, SAC-Cu/NC has a specific surface area of up to 537.8 m2/g and microporous structure. This SAC-Cu/NC catalyst with high specific surface area is favorable for promoting mass transfer and exposing more active sites (Fig. S9). High-energy plasma beam treatment leads to a large number of defects in the carbon support, as evidenced by the I D:I G value of 1.08 in the Raman spectrum of the SAC-Cu/NC (Fig. S10). Part of the defects trap metal ions to form Cu single metal sites and part of them are derived into oxygen-containing functional groups on the supports, as confirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Fig. S11). In order to further investigate the coordination environment and chemical state of SAC-Cu/NC, X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) were carried out at SAC-Cu/NC. The Cu K-edge XANES data show that SAC-Cu/NC is intermediate between CuO and Cu foil, indicating that the average oxidation valence state of Cu is between 0 and +2 (Fig. 6e). The main peak of the Fourier transform (FT)-EXAFS spectrum of SAC-Cu/NC is located at 1.49 Å, which corresponds to the Cu–N coordination in the first shell layer. In addition, the Cu–Cu peak of the Cu foil standard at around 2.2 Å was not clearly detected in SAC-Cu/NC, which confirms that Cu is present in the carrier as a single isolated atom (Fig. 6f). Based on the EXAFS fitting data, the localized structure around Cu in SAC-Cu/NC agrees well with the CuN3 model, which proves that Cu in SAC-Cu/NC exists in a coordination structure in the form of CuN3 (Fig. S12 and Table S5). Moreover, the atomic configuration of SAC-Cu/NC was further probed through the application of Cu K-edge wavelet transform (WT)-EXAFS. In comparison with the WT signal of Cu foil, the Cu–Cu coordination was not detected within SAC-Cu/NC. Instead, a distinct Cu–N signal was discerned, which provided further evidence that the Cu species existed in a monoatomic state in SAC-Cu/NC (Fig. 6g–i). In addition, the N 1s and Cu 2p results in the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of SAC-Cu/NC indicate that Cu is mainly coordinated to the N element, forming typical Cu–N species (Fig. S13). Moreover, test calculations on pyridine-type Cu-N3 sites (denoted as Cu-pd-N3) exhibit very large ORR and OER overpotentials of 1.24 and 0.86 eV, respectively, ruling out the possibility of the Cu-pd-N3 as bifunctional active sites (Fig. S14). Following electrochemical data demonstrated the excellent bifunctional activity of the prepared SAC-Cu/NC. Therefore, we successfully prepared a single-atom catalyst containing Cu-po-N3 sites. The previous results from EXAFS combined with DFT calculations show that the Cu-po-N3 structure can be successfully prepared by this method. The electrocatalytic activity of SAC-Cu/NC for OER and ORR was evaluated in a three-electrode system, with commercial RuO2 and Pt/C as benchmarks. SAC-Cu/NC demonstrates excellent OER performance with an overpotential of 317 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is lower 37 mV than that of commercial RuO2 (354 mV) (Fig. 7 a). The double-layer capacitance (C dl), indicative of the active site density of the catalyst, was calculated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements. SAC-Cu/NC exhibits a C dl of 2.5 mF cm−2, higher than that of commercial RuO2 (1.3 mF cm−2), indicating a high density of exposed active sites (Fig. 7b and Fig. S15). In addition, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA)-normalized LSV curves of SAC-Cu/NC showed slightly lower current densities than those of RuO2, suggesting a relative lower intrinsic activity of SAC-Cu/NC, which is consistent with the calculated results (Fig. S16). The Tafel slope of SAC-Cu/NC (72.5 mV dec−1) is lower than that of RuO2 (89.2 mV dec−1) (Fig. S17). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plots show that a charge transfer resistance (R ct) based on the equivalent circuit model for SAC-Cu/NC is 22 Ω, compared to that for RuO2 (35 Ω, Fig. S18). These results indicate fast OER kinetics for SAC-Cu/NC. Stability was assessed using the chronopotential (CP) method, where SAC-Cu/NC showed negligible activity decay over 14 h at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7c). These results confirm the excellent OER performance of the prepared SAC-Cu/NC catalyst. Moreover, NC has low ORR activity and is inert to OER (Fig. 7a and d). This suggests that the excellent bifunctional activity of SAC-Cu/NC is contributed by the Cu-po-N3 site. The TEM, AC-HAADF-STEM, and XPS characterization means after stability testing demonstrated that the SAC-Cu/NC catalyst did not agglomerate and remained as a single atom (Figs. S19 and S20). Fig. 7(d) presents the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of SAC-Cu/NC and Pt/C for ORR. SAC-Cu/NC exhibits superior ORR performance compared to Pt/C, with a higher onset potential (1.011 V) and half-wave potential (0.886 V). The Tafel slope of SAC-Cu/NC is 65.3 mV dec−1, 6.2 mV dec−1 lower than that of Pt/C, indicating faster ORR kinetics (Fig. S21). Durability, evaluated by an accelerated durability test (ADT), showed that SAC-Cu/NC maintained almost unchanged LSV curves before and after ADT (Fig. 7e). In addition, the activity of Pt/C could only be maintained at 88.6% after the CP test, whereas SAC-Cu/NC could still maintain 92.7% of activity, which further indicates that SAC-Cu/NC has good stability and durability (Fig. S22). As shown in Fig. S23, the prepared SAC-Cu/NC catalyst exhibited excellent methanol resistance, which was superior to that of the Pt/C catalyst. As a bifunctional ORR and OER electrocatalyst, the ΔE index, defined as the potential gap between the potential at 10 mA cm−2 for OER and half-wave potential for ORR, is used to evaluate electrocatalytic bifunctional activity [53,54]. Fig. 7(f) shows LSV curves for bifunctional OER and ORR activities of SAC-Cu/NC and Pt/C+RuO2. SAC-Cu/NC delivers a low ΔE value of 0.666 V, outperforming the commercial Pt/C+RuO2 catalysts (0.718 V). Moreover, it is noted that the bifunctional ORR/OER performance of the prepared SAC-Cu/NC catalyst is superior to most of the reported bifunctional catalysts, suggesting the advantages of the prepared SAC-Cu/NC (Table S6). Further, SAC-Fe/NC and SAC-Co/NC catalysts were prepared using a similar strategy under the condition of changing only the metal precursor. The bifunctional activity of SAC-Cu/NC is high than that of the SAC-Fe/NC and SAC-Co/NC, in consistent with our calculation results (Figs. S24–S27). To further assess the utility of SAC-Cu/NC, it was used as the air-cathode catalyst in an R-ZABs (Fig. 7g). The SAC-Cu/NC-based R-ZABs exhibit a stable open circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.49 V, higher than that of the Pt/C+RuO2-based R-ZABs (1.40 V) (Fig. 7h). Power density curves reveal a peak power density of 170 mW cm−2 for SAC-Cu/NC-based R-ZABs, 1.3 times higher than that of Pt/C+RuO2-based R-ZABs (Fig. 7i). Galvanostatic charge-discharge measurements show a stable charge-discharge platform with a small voltage gap of 0.88 V (Fig. 7j). After over 240 h of charge-discharge testing, the voltage gap increased by only 0.01 V, indicating excellent stability of the assembled R-ZABs. In contrast, the Pt/C+RuO2-based ZABs displayed significant voltage gap deterioration after 87 h, demonstrating undesirable charge-discharge performance. The robust performance of the SAC-Cu/NC-based R-ZABs confirms the potential of SAC-Cu/NC catalysts for practical device applications. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, through a combination of density functional theory calculations and experimental validations, we have demonstrated the potential of pyrrole-type TM-po-N3 for bifunctional oxygen reduction reaction and oxygen evolution reaction catalysis in R-ZABs. We systematically explored the structure-activity relationships of TM-po-N3 catalysts, revealing that the dependence of ORR and OER activities of such catalysts on the linear relationship between the free energy of adsorption of reaction intermediates is different, thereby limiting the bifunctional activity of TM-po-N3. Among TM-po-N3 catalysts, Cu-po-N3 was identified as having the highest catalytic activity, attributable to interactions between spin-polarized out-of-plane 3dxz , 3dyz , and 3dz2 orbitals in Cu and 2s+2p orbitals in intermediates. Experimental results confirmed the theoretical predictions, showing that the synthesized Cu-SAC/NC catalyst exhibited superior bifunctional performance with a small potential gap of 0.666 V, surpassing the commercial benchmark based on noble metal catalysts. Moreover, the Cu-SAC/NC-based R-ZABs demonstrated a high peak power density of 170 mW cm−2 along with excellent long-term stability over 240 h with minimal voltage gap increase. This work not only provides a practical electrocatalyst for R-ZABs but also deepens our understanding of the structure-activity relationships in bifunctional catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Efficient catalysis of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is essential for the rechargeable zinc-air batteries (R-ZABs). However, challenges remain due to the scarcity of effective bifunctional electrocatalysts and limited understanding of the structure-activity relationships. Pyrrole-type single-atom catalysts (SACs) with unique electronic structures have emerged as promising electrocatalysts. In this work, we combine density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental studies to systematically explore the structure-activity relationships and potential of pyrrole-type transition metal-N3 (TM-po-N3) as bifunctional catalysts. DFT calculations reveal that differences in the dependence of ORR and OER activities on the free energy of adsorption of reaction intermediates significantly affect the TM-po-N3 bifunctional activity and identify magnetic Cu-po-N3 as the best candidate. The bifunctional activity of Cu-po-N3 originates from interactions between spin-polarized out-of-plane Cu_3d and O_2s+2p orbitals. Theoretical predictions are validated experimentally, showing that the synthesized Cu-SAC/NC exhibits excellent bifunctional performance with a small potential gap of 0.666 V. Additionally, the assembled R-ZABs display a high-power density of 170 mW cm−2 and long-term stability, with the charge-discharge voltage gap increasing by only 0.01 V over 240 h. This work provides new insights into the design of efficient bifunctional catalysts.
